text: The server was so busy the night we visited that she forgot to put in our food order.
2 weeks ago, I decided to set up a birthday dinner in this establishment and was wary with the reviews I've read in City Search but it seems to be a perfect scene.
My boyfriend and I went one Friday night to find that the place was empty except for one other table.
Amazing crust (and I hate pizza crust typically), great cheese, sauce isn't too sugary.
After being seated took our waiter 10 mintues to get us a menu, 15 minutes to come back for our order, by the time we finally got our food it was almost 1 1/2 hour since getting there.
The eggplant parmasean was AWESOME (I don't even like eggplant) but my main course was just ok (shrimp with pasta).
Ive been to Jacques-Imo in New Orleans, the wait is long (3+ hours) but the food and service more than makes up for it.
The prices weren't bad though - dinner ended up at $80 with tip and we had a couple drinks as well.
I ordered the fried catfish, which had very little to no seasoning, the yams, and mac and cheese which were just okay.

Ok I got the edamame and something from the sushi chef for free, but the quality of food is more important to me than a free small dish (maybe that's why the restaurant gives it to attact new customers.
While dining on a delicate lamb carpaccio, and grilled skate wing, the owner explained that due to low lunch-time patronage, they may be discontinuing lunch altogether.
the service was slow took ten mins to get me a glass of water.
We preferred to gaze at our burgers while avoiding having to look at the wait staff, but no complaints.
When my brother and I we had too much pizza in New York, we would like to order something else from the menu.

About 10 of us came here for drinks last friday, the atmosphere was good for chatting and hanging out, but not enough lounge or bar space, they should open up the back area w/ more loungable chairs or booths if they want to catch any after dinner sort of bar crowd.
When we went to dinner here, the place was empty, which should have been a clue.
The other two entrees that were ordered were very large portions.
Try the olive cream cheese or the lox spread on a whole wheat everything bagel.
When I asked the waitress, she told me they couldn't afford the salmon, and had changed the dish (though not on the menu).
There were a lot of scensters who couldnt afford dinner hanging in the waiting area so we got bumped around a lot.
For the price ($8), the quality of the buffet is great!
The Food The menu features a wide array of Hawaiian- and Asian-flavored appetizers and entrees.
seems everyone ordered sushi there were tons of delivery orders (we can tell as we sat near the back).
A 3 course-meal took 2 1/2 hours, including 20 - 30 minutes waiting to get the check after dessert.
Bernard is a great host; it didn't bother me a bit that he recited the entire menu to my wife.
Ive had better burgers and fries at the local dinner in my neighborhood: 3 guys dinner on 96th and Madison Avenue.
We were so excited since I was reading great review of this place, however we were disappointed with the taste of the food.
Also, they upped their prices, so I have their old menu, and was surprised when my bill came to over $5 more than it used to (I know, not a huge deal).
If people are late, you could lose your reservation and/or the staff does pressure you to start ordering even if your whole party hasnt arrived.
Seating is usually very prompt but expect a wait at peak times such as Sunday Brunch.
Their bagels have the perfect softness to them, but on the outside there's a bit of crispiness to give it a bit of texture.
Great value for the price-- lunch is an even better value, with entree and appetizer for between $8-10 or so.
Ten minutes later the manager relented and dropped off a glass of water with an upturned nose.
The servers were snobby and got mad at me when I asked if they serve by the slice.
The manager claimed that he could not compensate us for anything on the bill which just shows the lack of sophistication from the entire group.
While waiting for a table, tried to get a drink from a bartender who seemed more interested in arguing with his waiters.
Nice decor - but the place is so crowded and noisy you can't enjoy it.
So inexcpensive that you'd wonder about the sanity of the owners, if they weren't such good cooks.

We sat at the bar and were constantly bumped by the waitress flying past; had fabulously fresh raw oysters with pieces of shell in every bite; lobsters rolls were tasty but the large pieces of meat were tough; the apple crumble was excellent but the ice cream was over-frozen and the stench of frying oil was nearly unbearable.
The place was so dark, I needed the table candle to read the menu and could not properly see what I was eating.

The Scene You won't blink twice at the restaurant's spartan decor: As the packed crowds and critics' praises wallpapering the front wall agree, this longtime local favorite is truly one of the area's most exquisite finds.
the waitress came to ask me how my NY Strip was, and I could not give her an answer b/c no one gave me a steak knife.
The staff was courteous and explained the menu with detail.
We politely asked our server for the regular menu, but were told that for large parties they could only offer us the banquet menu (would have gone elsewhere had we known).
While the service and setting were average, the food was excellent.
It took 1 1/4 hours to get our appetizers (how long does salad take) and when we complained to the manager, he barely listened.
Not including the tip for our server, who we saw twice in an hour?
The ravioli was the better of the two, but the serving was tiny, and the skin a bit rubbery.
we live down the street and have eaten here many times for lunch and dinner, and the food is consistently terrific.
Next, follow up with another Cosmo and try the chicken fingers (not your lil brothers), Hawaiian rib eye, filet mignon, or trusty burger.
Our waiter seemed to really care about getting us to the show on time, and made some good reccomendations on the menu for doing it.
The service was polite, friendly and prompt, the characters walking around entertained the kids but werent intrusive to our meal.
However, another server kept hovering over our table, wanting to take our half-finished plates away.
The waitstaff are surprisingly uninformed and unintelligent, and I say this even though I liked my waiter.
Main courses we had (beef, lobster sukiyaki, black seabass, striped seabass) tasted too much like homestyle authentic Chinese food except for the sukiyaki.
The bill came out to like $100pp, and noone touched their food, and drinks were left untouched because after the first bite/sip you want to never touch it again.
We hunted the waitress to at least pay for the drinks.

The place was packed and while our food took time to be prepared, our waiter earned points for his sparkling conversation to pass time and for also knowing practically every ingredient of every special under consideration.
The atmosphere's a bit grungy, yes, but the music and the coffee are good.
We had no problems with our resevations and found the service and the meal well worth a wait, had we run into one.
the place has an awesome decore, with fish swiming below certain tables.
The not so goods: very pricey appetizers - $12 for a half cup of fried clams, $6 for two corn on the cob and $6 for a small plate of fries.
Sure the food was - as always - very good, but we were quite outrageous about the waitress.

So are cooked plates: Marinated Kobe beef practically melts on its skewers, soy-buttered scallops collapse with sweet brine and Chawanmushi custard, quivering in eel-soy broth with black truffles and foie gras, is over the top.

text: With the large crowds here and the larger menu, be prepared to wait for your dinner to arrive at your table.
The third time, after, an hour and a half of waiting, my friend went up to the host to check the status.

Right after we finished the main course (the organic chicken was dry), but before we finish drinking the wine the check was placed on the table, and the waitress came back and picked it up three times.
Appetizers are the safest bet, including a bountiful calamari plate or the appropriately earthy mushroom polenta.
the decor could be a bit better, and if there was a small bar the overall atmosphere would be a bit more inviting (especially for regulars).

The trick to the tomato and onions is ask for it light on the onions, heavy on the tomatoes, order steak for one less person than you have in your party and if the steak is too rare, you can cook the individual pieces more by placing them on the platter around the edges.
I will be back not only because the price was so unbelievable but the atmosphere was just plain COOL and the food was spectacular.
Went with a girlfriend, waited for over an hour while we had drinks, food was ok, service was terrible.
Went here with my husband on a Saturday night for dinner since the place looked like it had great atmosphere.
The service was great -- my glass was refilled without having to ask, we were greeted by the manager that day to ask how our food was.
The waiter knew about every item on the menu and explained it very well.

dinner on 1st floor (street level) a bit noisy, 2nd floor has bed-style seating that is good for dessert drinks (do not attempt to have entree on the bed, what a mess it will be trying to eat rice dishes with sauce while half-lying down).
The only dishes that were good were the chicken kebob (not hard to make) and the desserts, which were rice pudding.
The Clinton-frequented restaurant stands handsomely on a quiet residential corner, and the modern interior includes a long dining room, a small bar and harsh lighting.
I like the somosas, chai, and the chole, but the dhosas and dhal were kinda dissapointing.
i got a steak special that was way overpriced ($12 more then the steak on the menu and no warning from the waitress) and it was cooked to the wrong temperature.
Watch out for the overworked, stressed out waitress who dumps tapa dishes on the table and leaves w/out announcing what it is.
At 1:15 we were still waiting for our plates!
The service was non-existant, the manager spent all of his time at the bar.
For dessert, go with the delicate, subtle flan over the pasty rice pudding.
The atmosphere was warm, sexy, and very romantic but the lighting wasn't good for reading the menu.
The mango salsa with fish cake was too sour, the apple suace for pork chop too sweet.

text: Had a mouthwatering sardinian Stuffed Squid and a Catfish fiumarola from Rome( think was capers and anchovies sauce).
The waiter recommended I choose a bottle for the entire meal.
The Scene Hunky waiters dub diners darling and it sounds like they mean it.

The situation was verified by taking 3 dishes that were over an hour late off the bill and free desserts and coffee but the experience left most of us never wanting to go to the supposed hip cool 66 ever again.
After being ignored by our waiter we complained to the manager who assured us everything would improve.
Anyway we get a table and order some appetizers from one of the waitresses who was pleasently nice.
The round pizza doesn't taste as good as I recall, it's still wonderful, but the Sicilian is to die for.
My vegetable Napoleon was good; although i first got the veggie burger because the waitress mis-heard and stood my friend up for another 15 minutes of waiting to have it served.
Our waitress did not take our drink order until I finally flagged her down and even then she seemed disinterested in our meal.
I would have told the wait staff if anyone had asked me if I enjoyed my meal, but no one asked.
Telly's has the best octopus ever and the fish was so good on the grill.
Food was much better than the average Indian place in the area, and more interesting.
The meat, onions, and cheese were good as was the roll, but I'd go back if I could forego the sauce.
My party felt like we got put in a dining room for tourist, which must have been the penalty box area for the disgruntled wait staff on duty.
went there for sunday brunch after a wonderful massage - the food was terrible-bland/tasteless, cold, expensive.
about 10 minutes apart each, so we were all eating cold eggs by the time we got our food.
After our meal,the manager, even took some of his time to sit with us and give us a lesson in Sake 101.
Food was average, the appetizers were better than the main courses.
The Scene Shun Lee Palace is popular with midtown locals, possibly because the upscale room means you can impress a client and have Chinese for lunch at the same time.
If you don't want to wait 45 minutes for a table or a long time for service then don't go @ 9pm on a Friday or Saturday night.
But on a recent Sunday brunch excursion, I was greeted by a uniformly unfriendly staff - starting with the hostess and extending to foul faced wait staff.
The food was served promptly and was really hot.
We had reservations and when we showed up the manager told us the wait was over 45 mins.
We initially ordered a bottle of wine and the waitress though we may not like it, so she offered us a taste.
My dining companion and I have nothing but raves about the  environment and the Food.
My husband and I had dinner here last week and the food was very good.
The nachos were very very good, but the onion bloom felt too greasy and the calamari was soggy.
This much heralded restaurant brought my wife and I some excitement as we walked in the door, but we were met with an awkward maitre'd who barely spoke to us at all and just seemed standoff-ish.
I love the shrimp summer role, chicken kabob's, and all the chicken and shrimp dishes.
From beginning appetizers, the scallops were incredible, to the delicious chocolate souffle with rasberry mint sorbet, we were delighted by the taste sensations.

text: Our waiter brought out three main courses, but the fourth wasn't ready so we had to wait for 10 minutes for the last dish to arrive, but they were very nice and gave us free red pepper hummus while we waited.

I love Chinese food and have been looking for the alternative to the greasy stuff on every corner of New York- ya, you know, the stinky take-out joints that leave you smelling like dinner for 100 for the rest of the night!
We recently had brunch at this establishment with two other couples and I have to say I was majorly dissapointed with the service and how we were treated.
My bass was even worse - smothered in some kind of tomato sauce that just did not go with fish and the spinach that accompanied the dish was extremely dry and flavorless.
Once at the table our waitress managed on two occasions to take 15 minutes bringing drinks to our table, our plates sat uncleared on the table for just as long.

Miyagi is my sushi restaurant of choice in the Village; it's never insanely crowded, the service is very sweet (I've never experienced any of the nastiness described in prior reviews), and the tabs are small.

I couple of weeks ago we went to Supper in the east village and it was so bad that we got up and left and the only way to save the evening of horrible food was to go to Blue Ribbon Bakery and have at least one thing off the menu.
Been here a few times and food has always been good but service really suffers when it gets crowded.

I was surprised by the small ice cream dessert from the restaurant to the birthday girl free of charge, but if they're going to give a nice service the one ice cream scoop on a stick didn't leave a strong enough impression.
We went for Buffet lunch and the sauce was water down, not at all spicy.
The service was less than spectacular (two waiters fought in front of us over which one got our table) and the bread put out as an appetizer was sub-par.
The only apparent flavor in any of the dishes was heat, and a table of four gourmands left at least half of our meals on our plates.
impressive balcony seating and while they forgot to give us the cold appetizers, the waiter and maitre'd more than made up for it by being most accomodating to us.
Mussels in deeply aromatic lemongrass broth make an excellent starter, as do the light and spicy house samosas.
the service is pushy and the food looks good but is completely average (chewy steak, tasteless rice and beans).
The waiter appeared promptly, took our order, bought us drinks and was never to be seen again.
The waiter kept coming up and asking to take our plates while we were still eating and the manager stood and stared at us through half our meal!
Great for those hungover mornings when you need a decent pint and delicious, homemade food that will tide you over for the whole day.

The waitress was no where to be found at all throughout the course of the meal, did not refill a single drink nor did she bother to inquire about my satisfaction with the food or even bring the check at the conclusion of the meal.
(Though the filet won't be enough if both have hearty apitites.
The food is decent, average bistro food, the decor is nice, but the service is poor, the waiters always seems to have to many tables andcant keep up with a good services.
I'm totally into the space-age vibe of this place, but I wish they had more tables to sit down at.
They were rude, didn't know their drinks and were unable to demonstrate any professionalism in their service mentality.
While the staff was kind and attentive, our waiter never once broke a smile, even when I told him it was my friend's birthday, although he did bring a dessert with a candle at the end of the meal.
Start by enjoying the atmosphere while having a glass of wine at the bar and we you are ready, go and enjoy your food!
My only advice is: increase portion sizes; and develop a special drink list.
The Food This isn't for those on a budget, but portions are generous.
Aside from the fact the maitre de claimed the dining room was 'full', we were seated at a great table overlooking the lobby of the hotel and ordered the 5 course tasting menu.

Bouley has done an excellent job creating this dining establishment with almost a museum sense, the artworks on the wall have a very Klimty feeling and the gold ceiling completes the rest of the experience.
The food is delish, you just have to know the manners to consume, if you don't want to be frustrated with the service.

Mac cheese is nothing to write home about; the beet salad is boring, mostly lettuce; tuna sandwhich - boring, mostly mayo; the french fries looked re-fried and were cold; the excellent pork sandwich came on one of those supermarket hot-dog buns.
Get a pitcher of red or white sangria and choose from a large selection of tapas.
They also have a great deal of 2 cheese slices and a drink for $3.
Bins of fresh bagels rest behind the counter, and there are always a few customers sitting at one of the few tables inside or on one of two wooden benches out front.
There is nothing else on the menu except for exotic teas and cold beverages, but with a meal this cheap and delightful, who would care?
THe bartendars were right on top of getting us our wine and setting up free blue cheese dip and chips for us.

Includes a diverse array of entrees ranging from Boar (prepared in your choice of either the French or Asian tradition), Mussels, or Pad Thai that grace the menu all at once, each one prepared in a distinctly different and delicate sauce.
After all that, the waiter tried to backpedal saying its too hard to time the cooking of miso soup with the sushi bar offerings.
Anyway, I went down on a Wednesday night to see if they had a long wait and the hostess said they had a table to accomodate my party.
The Food The classic Italian menu gets off to a good start with Queen's famous bread basket, which is loaded with a slew of crunchy, yeasty homemade varieties.
For the main course, try out the Beef Negimaki.
For lunch, opt for an outstanding, triple-decker roast turkey club or brioche burger with skin-on fries.

I understand the area and folks you need not come here for the romantic, alluring ambiance or the five star service featuring a sommlier and a complicated maze of captain and back waiters - you come for the authentic foods, the tastes, the experiance.
The service can be lacking at times, but the desserts and overall experience certainly counter this flaw.

Had a party of 7 people for dinner here on a busy night for the restaurant, and our meal was excellent and served with extreme consistency (all appetizers and main courses were served at the right times, with none of the dishes served at the wrong temperature).
however, we went for lunch and were the only ones eating there and yet the service seemed eager for us to be done and to get out.
People will literally spend their entire lunch break waiting and for what - an average fastfood burger.
As for the food, brunch was average, I would not get the same dish again, and they were slow to serve us.
This place would be so much better served by being run by a group that actually understands customer service.
The only redeeming factor of the night was the dessert which was very good but certainly not worth the cost of an overall horible experience.
Although when I went to eat dinner at Bombay Talkie on a crazy busy night, my waiter was extremely helpful through the menu, polite and polished.
The smoked salmon appetizer was pretty good (it comes with goat cheese, calpers and onions).
The server came by only once to pour additional wine for the table; the rest of the time, we had to fish the bottle out of the two-table communal bucket ourselves.
